data.title: The 100 Most Common Italian Words You NEED to Know
data.meta_description: In this lesson, we'll cover the 100 most common Italian words you'll need to know as a foreigner. We've selected the ones that are more useful for practical purposes. We'll also look at plenty of example sentences to help you learn these words more easily. Let's get started!
data.text:
The average Italian vocabulary lists the definitions for about 200,000 lemmas. However, native Italian speakers can get by with just a tiny fraction of that huge number. You can actually live in the country if you know as little as 7,000 words.

In this lesson, we‚Äôll cover the 100 most common Italian words you‚Äôll need to know as a foreigner. We‚Äôve selected the ones that are more useful for practical purposes.

We‚Äôll also look at plenty of example sentences to help you learn these words more easily. Let‚Äôs get started!

The 100 most common Italian words

10 Italian words you will use on a daily basis

ciao hello, bye buongiorno good morning, good day buonasera good evening arrivederci goodbye s√¨ yes no no grazie thanks, thank you prego you‚Äôre welcome mi scusi excuse me, sorry per favore please

In Italy, ciao is an informal greeting you use with friends and family. Buongiorno and buonasera are polite greetings. You can also use ciao to part ways in informal settings. If you need to say bye to your boss or a stranger, use arrivederci. This literally means ‚Äúto see each other again‚Äù.

S√¨ and no are the translations for ‚Äúyes‚Äù and ‚Äúno‚Äù, respectively. If you need to write them, make sure you put an accent mark on s√¨, because si is a different Italian word.

Grazie and prego are the words for ‚Äúthank you‚Äù and ‚Äúyou‚Äôre welcome‚Äù. If you want to say ‚Äúyes, please‚Äù, you actually have to use s√¨, grazie. This literally translates as ‚Äúyes, thank you‚Äù. I know it may sound strange, but that‚Äôs the way it goes in Italy!

If you want to apologize or ask something of a stranger, use mi scusi. It works for both ‚Äúsorry‚Äù and ‚Äúexcuse me‚Äù. If you want to ask a favor, use per favore, which literally means ‚Äúfor favor‚Äù but translates as ‚Äúplease‚Äù.

Examples:

Buongiorno signor Rossi, come sta?

Good morning Mr. Rossi, how are you?

Vuoi del t√®? ‚Äì Si, grazie.

Would you like some tea? ‚Äì Yes, please.

Mi scusi, sa dove trovo la stazione degli autobus?

Excuse me, do you know where the bus station is?

The 10 most important Italian verbs

essere to be avere to have stare to stay fare to do andare to go venire to come dovere must, have to potere can, be able to volere to want sapere to know

Essere and avere are used in compound verb tenses like some Italian past tenses (ho mangiato, ‚ÄúI have eaten‚Äù), while stare is used in the gerund mood (sto mangiando, ‚ÄúI am eating‚Äù).

The four Italian modal verbs are dovere, potere, volere and sapere. Unlike other verbs, these can be followed by a verb in the infinitive mood (the basic form of Italian verbs ending in ‚Äìare, ‚Äìere and ‚Äìire).

Examples:

Sono andato in farmacia.

I went to the pharmacy.

Sto leggendo un libro giallo.

I am reading a crime book.

Devo pulire i piatti entro sera.

I have to do the dishes by evening.

Enrico sa suonare la chitarra.

Enrico can play the guitar.

The 10 most common Italian words for asking questions

cosa, che cosa what chi who dove where quando when perch√© why come how quanto how much quanti how many come mai how come a che ora at what time

If you want to ask a question in Italian, you don‚Äôt have to change the order of the subject and verb or add a helper verb. All you need to do is add a ‚Äú?‚Äù at the end of the sentence.

Stefano abita in quella casa.

Stefano lives in that house.

Stefano abita in quella casa?

Does Stefano live in that house?

You‚Äôll probably use the interrogative pronouns cosa, chi, dove, quando, perch√© and come the most. These always come first in the question, just like their English translations. It‚Äôs a good idea to learn these well because you‚Äôll probably use them pretty much daily, likely more than once. Here are a few examples:

Cosa vuoi mangiare per cena?

What would you like to eat for dinner?

Chi ha mangiato l‚Äôultimo pezzo di torta?

Who ate the last piece of cake?

Dove ho lasciato i miei occhiali?

Where did I leave my glasses?

Quando partirai per Parigi?

When are you leaving for Paris?

Perch√© il cane si morde la coda?

Why is the dog biting its own tail?

Come si scrive questa parola?

How do you spell this word?

Quanto costa una bottiglia d‚Äôacqua?

How much does a bottle of water cost?

The 10 most common Italian words for travelling

stazione (ferroviaria) (train) station aeroporto airport valigia/bagaglio suitcase/luggage biglietto ticket museo museum treno train autobus bus hotel hotel chiesa church camera doppia/singola single/double room

If you ever get the chance to visit Italy, you‚Äôll probably need to get your bearings. This section and the next will help you avoid getting lost.

You can use these words in lots of different ways, but there are a few common sentences and questions you‚Äôll often hear or need to ask, such as:

Quanto costa un biglietto per‚Ä¶?

How much is a ticket to‚Ä¶?

Dove posso comprare‚Ä¶?

Where can I buy‚Ä¶?

Vorrei prenotare una camera singola/doppia.

I would like to book a single/double room.

Ho perso il mio bagaglio!

I lost my luggage!

Devo arrivare all‚Äôhotel‚Ä¶

I have to get to the hotel‚Ä¶

Ho perso l‚Äôaereo / il treno / l‚Äôautobus.

I missed the plane / the train / the bus.

The 10 most common Italian words for going places

via street strada road piazza square citt√† city paese small town sinistra left destra right dritto straight ahead casa home chilometro kilometer

You also need to know how to read directions. Use a sinistra to translate ‚Äúto the left‚Äù, and a destra to say ‚Äúto the right‚Äù. If someone says you need to andare dritto, it means you have to ‚Äúgo straight ahead‚Äù.

If you need to ask where something is or you happen to get lost, you can say:

Dove si trova‚Ä¶?

Where is‚Ä¶?

Mi sono perso!

I got lost!

Sto cercando Via Manzoni.

I‚Äôm looking for Via Manzoni.

Sa dirmi come raggiungere Piazza Navona?

Can you tell me how to get to Piazza Navona?

Just a quick note: If you‚Äôre used to calculating distances in miles, remember that the numbers you see on Italian road signs are always in chilometri, which is the Italian word for kilometers. So, ‚ÄúBERGAMO 12‚Äù means that the city of Bergamo is 12 kilometers away, even if no unit is given. A kilometer is about 0.62 miles.

The 10 most common Italian words for talking about time

giorno day sera evening notte night ora hour minuto minute oggi today domani tomorrow ieri yesterday mese month settimana week

You need to know how to answer the question quando?, ‚Äúwhen?‚Äù. It‚Äôs a pretty common question in Italian, so it‚Äôs worth learning how to respond. Here are some common questions and sentences for talking about time:

Che ore sono?

What time is it?

Che giorno √® oggi?

What day is today?

A che ora chiude la banca?

What time does the bank close?

Come si dicono i giorni della settimana in italiano?

How do you say the days of the week in Italian?

Find out how to say the days of the week in Italian here! üòâ

The 10 most common Italian words to go shopping

supermercato supermarket cassa check-out, cash register carrello shopping cart spesa grocery shopping borsa bag carne meat pesce fish pane bread frutta e verdura fruits and vegetables carta di credito credit card

If you‚Äôre grocery shopping in Italy, it‚Äôs good to know some of the most common words you‚Äôll find in supermarkets.

Another quick note: If you‚Äôre planning on staying in the country for a while and doing your grocery shopping almost every day, make sure you bring your own tote bag. Supermarkets, supermercati, will charge you 2-10 cents for every compostable bag you request at their place (they used to be free!), and the cost can add up pretty quickly.

That said, here are a few common sentences you need to know:

Posso pagare con carta di credito?

Can I pay by credit card?

Dov‚Äô√® il reparto della carne / del pesce?

Where is the meat/fish department?

Dov‚Äô√® la cassa?

Where is the cash register?

Mi sa dire dov‚Äô√® il supermercato pi√π vicino?

Can you tell me where the nearest supermarket is?

The 10 most common Italian words for eating out

ristorante restaurant pizzeria pizzeria men√π menu primo first course secondo main course dolce dessert tavolo table forchetta fork cameriere waiter conto bill

A full Italian meal is made up of three parts: il primo (first course), il secondo (main course) and il dolce (dessert). If you want to reserve a table, just say:

Vorrei prenotare un tavolo per‚Ä¶ due/tre/quattro.

I would like to reserve a table for‚Ä¶ two/three/four.

Once you‚Äôve finished your meal, it‚Äôs not typical for Italian waiters to bring the bill to your table unprompted. You‚Äôll have to ask for it directly or walk up to the cash register yourself. Eating out is a social event, and waiters will let you stay for as long as you like without rushing you to leave! To ask for the bill, just say:

Mi porta il conto, per favore?

Would you bring me the bill, please?

It‚Äôs also pretty common for people to drop their fork or some other piece of cutlery on the floor by accident. If that happens, just call for the waiter with cameriere, mi scusi (do NOT shout!) and then say:

Mi porterebbe una nuova forchetta?

Would you bring me a new fork?

Or un nuovo cucchiaio, if you need a spoon. Or a new glass, un nuovo bicchiere.

The 10 most common Italian words for talking about relationships

famiglia family mamma mom pap√† dad fratello brother sorella sister ragazzo boy, boyfriend ragazza girl, girlfriend uomo man donna woman bambino/a child (m/f)

Fratello and sorella are the Italian words for ‚Äúbrother‚Äù and ‚Äúsister‚Äù, but there‚Äôs no word in Italian that translates ‚Äúsibling‚Äù. You‚Äôll have to use either of the two, while in the plural you have to say fratelli e/o sorelle, ‚Äúbrothers and/or sisters‚Äù.

If you‚Äôre talking about a little boy, use bambino. For little girls, use bambina. You‚Äôll also find the masculine/feminine distinction in ragazzo (‚Äúboy‚Äù) and ragazza (‚Äúgirl‚Äù). These can also be used to translate ‚Äúboyfriend‚Äù and ‚Äúgirlfriend‚Äù.

Here are some common sentences you might come across:

Hai fratelli o sorelle?

Do you have any brothers or sisters?

Quanti siete in famiglia?

How many of you are in the family?

Il pap√† e la mamma sono sposati.

Dad and Mom are married.

10 beautiful Italian words

At last, you‚Äôre going to learn some Italian words that will put a smile on your face!

amore love felicit√† happiness sorriso smile auguri best wishes compleanno birthday amico friend cane dog gatto cat fiore flower cuore heart

Isn‚Äôt it interesting how cuore, the Italian word for ‚Äúheart‚Äù, and amore, rhyme? üôÇ The same goes for fiore, ‚Äúflower‚Äù.

To wish happy birthday to someone, use buon compleanno. If you want to say ‚Äúbest wishes‚Äù instead, you can simply say auguri or also tanti auguri, literally ‚Äúmany wishes‚Äù.

Examples:

Tanti auguri di buon compleanno!

Many happy birthday wishes!

Chi √® il tuo amico del cuore?

Who is your BFF?

Cuore e amore fanno rima.

‚ÄúCuore‚Äù and ‚Äúamore‚Äù rhyme.

Ho raccolto un bel fiore.

I picked a beautiful flower.
